passages.text: Australia | Metals & Mining
Equity ResearchAugust 28,2025
FY25-Cash Flows In the, P&L Calibrations On Ramp Up Noise

P&L results were messy, calculated underlying EBITDA (not provided) was a modest miss to our expectation with higher operating cost alignment. Cash movements reconciled as expected. Unit costs included $7.8m/$2.6/lb impairment benefit in FY25, with $12.1m/-$3/lb inventory provision which,using the same accounting treatment, could be included in FY26 unit cost guidance of US$44-48/lb. The PLS Review modestly increased our capex assumption and timing. BUY, PT AUD8.40.

**FY25 Results - Messy P&L for first full operating year, but no material surprises.** EBITDA was not reported, we calculated underlying EBITDA at $28m which was a small miss to our expectation on cost alignment (Figure 1). Non-cash cost of sales of US$53.4m includes an impairment reversal adjustment of $45.5m, D&A was in line with our expectations, a $10.2m positive change in inventories, and a separate non-cash inventory impairment of US$12.1m.A $29m customer prepayment received in June for a July resulted in a modest negative operating cash flow despite positive mine cash margins.

**Balance sheet.** Closing cash of $89m was pre-guided, net cash of $2.5m was better than expected. The $86.5m term loan remains outstanding with $13.5m repaid and a $50m undrawn revolver, yielding a net debt of roughly $2.5m and pro-forma liquidity of ~$139m. We expect PDN to dip back into a net debt position in H2 FY26 before transitioning to a sustained net cash position over the course of FY26 as LH ramps up.

**Unit costs inclusive of impairment.** Disclosed cost of production of $129.1m, selling costs of $9.1m, and inventory changes of -$10.2m equal a total cost of sales of $128.1m, or $42.4/lb average unit cost of sales. Reconciliation is found through the $7.8m inventory impairment sold in the period. We note a residual non-cash balance of $12.1m inventory provision which,using the same accounting treatment, could be applied to FY26 unit cost guidance of US $44-48/lb, or a ~$3/lb non-cash benefit to unit costs. It is unclear if this has been factored into guidance or not.

**Patterson Lake South update.** The PLS engineering review has revised some Triple R assumptions, specifically timing and capex. Revised construction capex of $1.226bn was higher than our $900m forecast, however LoM sustaining capex of $325m was meaningfully lower than our $900m over the same duration. We have increased our total capex (growth and sustaining) by a net $130m. Timing was also revised to 2031, where we had already been forecasting production. We note provincial EIS decision is expected by end-CY25. We revised our production expectation to 2032. These changes decrease our asset based NPV by $338m/$0.85m.

**Referate** BUY, PT AUD8.40. Results were messy in the P&L, net cash movements were largely as expected and are the more important indicator through operational ramp up. FY26 continues to be pivotal, the delivery of the remaining haulage fleet in H1 FY26, and successful ramp up in production is critical for rebuilding confidence in project delivery.

**Earnings Changes.** We have updated our estimates to account for FY25 results. We have also revised our PLS model to account for higher growth capex, lower sustaining capex, and pushed our timing for first production back to 2032.
**Mitch Ryan * | Equity Analyst**
**Fahad Tariq, CPA, CA ^ | Equity Analyst**
**Hamish Wiltshire * | Equity Associate**
**James Lloyd * | Equity Associate**
Paladin is re- establishing itself as a key uranium supplier with the restart of its \(75\%\) owned Langer Heinrich Mine in Namibia, ramping up to 6MbU3Og a.

The recent acquisition of Fission Uranium secures full ownership of the Patterson Lake South project in Canada, targeting production of \(\sim 10Mlb\) p.a. by FY29. This acquisition enables cash flows from LHM to be reinvested into organic production growth.
We expect Paladin to be a key beneficiary of long- term positive uranium market dynamics, driven by global electrification, decarbonisation, and increased focus on national energy security.
Paladin is listed on both the ASX and TSX and offers a unique large- cap, liquid, and listed pure- play uranium exposure.
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View
Our price target (AU\\$8.40/C\\$7.50) is based on a blend of \(50\%\) 1.0x NPV, \(25\%\) 7x FY27 EV/EBITDA, and \(25\%\) 9x FY27 P/CF.

We incorporate a valuation for Langer Heinrich ramping to 5.7U3Og pa by FY27; Patterson Lake South Project being developed by FY29; and Michelin Project being developed by FY36. We also include a risk- weighted NPV for Resources at US\\$4.7/lb of Resource for the balance of the exploration and development portfolio.
In our upside scenario, we lift our uranium prices by \(20\%\) vs the current forecast price profile. PT AU\\$11.0/C\\$10.00.
We base our downside scenario on NPV only, modelling uranium prices \(20\%\) below our current forecasts. PT AU\\$2.5/C\\$2.50.

Top Material Issue(s): Key issues for the sector include the consideration of traditional owners of the land on which mines are located, net- zero targets and actions being taken to achieve set goals, and workforce safety and structure, for example, local community hired vs fly- in, fly- out workers.

Company Target(s): Since in production, PDN's ESG goals include 1) set meaningful targets for the reduction of carbon footprint, 2) implement opportunities to reduce scope 1 and scope 2 emissions, 3) maximised local and regional employment and provide opportunities for local communities, and 4) comply with modern slavery reporting requirements.

Qs to wight: 1) What is the water intensity of your Namibian operations and how are you addressing these needs? 2) Who are the traditional owners of the land on which you operate? What are your interactions with them? 3) What are your considerations about paying a 'fair' rent in the countries in which you operate vs achieving an appropriate return on capital for operating in that environment? 4) What are the key community concerns at your operations and how have you addressed them?
Langer Heinrich: Commencing fresh ore mining in 2025, ongoing ramp- up to 5.7 U3Og pa by FY27; and demonstration of long- term cost guidance.
Patterson Lake South Project: integration into the PDN portfolio; updated studies across FY26; approvals and development by FY29.
Michelin Project: Further studies and approvals.
Exploration portfolio: Further drilling and results, and changes in mining legislation should bring attention to these assets.

Paladin Energy (PDN.ASX) is re- establishing itself as a key global player in the uranium industry through the restart of the 6.0mlbpa Langer Heinrich uranium mine in Namibia at a time when uranium industry fundamentals are rapidly improving. We see minimal technical risk associated with the Langer restart, given the site's 11- year successful operational history, which saw it produce 43mlbs at a C1 cost of US\\$27/lb. Paladin also hosts a high- quality exploration and development portfolio that provides longer- term upside potential and enhances leverage to uranium markets. We expect Paladin to be a key beneficiary of long- term positive uranium market dynamics, driven by global electrification, decarbonisation, and increased focus on national energy security.

Our price target is based on a blend of \(50\%\) NPV, \(25\%\) EV/EBITDA, and \(25\%\) P/CF. We incorporate a valuation for exploration and development assets through a \(50\%\) risk- weighted NPV for Michelin and US\\$1/lb of Resource for the balance of the exploration and development portfolio.
Risks to our valuation include the following:

- Movements in the uranium price will have a material effect on earnings and sentiment towards the company share price.- Adverse movements in the USD/NAD and AUD/USD exchange rates will impact earnings and valuation metrics.- Access to funding may become a factor if further debt or equity is required ahead of the restart of Langer Heinrich.- Increased capital expenditure costs will drive balance sheet risk and impact valuation metrics.- Delayed commencement of production will impact the balance sheet, and may drive a need for further funding.- Increased mining and operating costs will reduce forecast cash flows and impact earnings and valuation metrics.- Inability to achieve mining production rates, uranium grade in Mineral Resource, recovery and dilution assumptions and metallurgical recovery rates could result in reduced production and increased unit costs, reducing cash flows, earnings, and valuation.- Reliable supply of sufficient power and water supplies by government owned and operated utilities is an external operating risk that is key to delivering on production targets, any disruption will impact production.- Increased freight and logistics costs and supply chain and resource disruptions due to events such as COVID-19 could impact on the capital works schedule and costs prior to restart and the ability to ramp up production once in operation.

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
